summary.seg: Cambridge, Jesus College, MS Q.D.4 (hereafter MS Q.D.4) is a composite manuscript, with all parts probably together by the later 15th century. The first two Parts of MS Q.D.4 probably date from the second half of the 14th century or the first half of the fifteenth century, the third Part dates from the late 12th or early 13th century, and the last Part contains just three surviving but badly damaged leaves (and a text stub) that probably date from the early 15th century. MS Q.D.4 has a medieval binding of tawed skin stained red over medieval wooden boards; the original strap-and-pin fastening is gone, but the groove for the strap is still visible in the fore-edge of the left cover and a hole for the pin plate is still visible on the right cover and the medieval head and tail bands are still partially visible, complete with original blue and and yellow decorative thread.

The volume has a complex codicological structure. The volume is comprised of four major Parts from four originally distinct medieval manuscript sources, but Parts 1 and 3 can also be further divided into codicological units where there is clear separation of scribal stints, or variations in mise-en-page, but where there are also shared elements such as shared rubricators or artists or layouts that indicate that the units were probably made in the same place and where the later units were always intended to be bound with the earlier ones. For example, in Part 3 (ff. 188-211; 212-243; 244-259; 260-267), there is a clear demarcation of codicological units between folios 243v and 244r: although the scribes change at the page division and the mise-en-page is not identical across the opening, the scribe of f. 244r continued the text seamlessly from f. 243v, and the same artist added decorative initials across both units using a distinctive ball ornament (see e.g., the initial 'R' on ff. 243v and 248r for a particularly close match).

The contents of the volume primarily relate to Christian theology, with a particular emphasis on sin, absolution and the act of Confession. Richard Rolle's works are well-represented here in Part 1, as are short quotations from a number of early Christian writers. The majority of the texts in MS Q.D.4 are in Latin, but words are often glossed in Middle English and some texts are copied primarily (or entirely) in Middle English. In Part 2, folios 172v-183r contain a selection of medical recipes, charms, dietary advice, and prognostic information in Middle English and Latin, written out by a scribe who also copied some of the sermons and other religious material in that Part. Regrettably, not much is known about the provenance of the volume before its arrival at Jesus College in 1664. Work by Rüdiger Spahl demonstrates that London, British Library, MS Harley 5235, ff. 1r-11v must have served as the direct exemplar for the copy of the Emendatio uitae by Richard Rolle Rolle, Richard, 1290?-1349 on ff. 74r-99v in this manuscript. According to Spahl, the two manuscripts contain fourteen shared textual omissions not found in any other copies of the text, and corrections made by the Harley scribe to the text of the Emendatio uitae after the main copying stint had been completed are also found in MS Q.D.4. Spahl supplies other evidence for the archetype-child relationship between these two manuscripts and positions both within his 'zeta' subgroup, but unfortunately, as little is known about the origin or provenance of MS Harley 5235, neither manuscript can be used to determine further details about the history of the other. The only substantial mark of ownership in MS Q.D.4 prior to the Jesus College shelfmarks is that of an untraced 'John Thrope' on f. 269v, but it was clearly well-used by its medieval and later owners judging by the frequent annotations and the addition of numbered tabs to allow readers to quickly find their desired position within the volume.

References: R. Spahl, De Emendatione Vitae: Eine Kritische Ausgabe Des Lateinischen Textes von Richard Rolle Mit Einer Übersetzung Ins Deutsche Und Untersuchungen Zu Den Lateinischen Und Englischen Handschriften, Studien Zur Wirkung Der Klassischen Antike, 6 (V&R UniPress, 2009)

Dr Sarah Gilbert
Project Cataloguer for the Curious Cures project
Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries

supportDesc.support: All leaves, except for pastedowns, are parchment.

foliation.note: Foliated in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the upper outer corner of each recto. One leaf after f. 50 was accidentally omitted by the foliator. Elsewhere, three folio designations were accidentally duplicated by the foliator. In order to produce a functional TEI-XML record, the omitted leaf is designated here as f. [50a], and the second of each duplicated leaf is designated here as ff. [160a], [187a] and [221a]. These temporary designations by the Curious Cures project are enclosed in [square brackets] throughout this record. M. R. James commented on the foliation error at f. 187 (and f. [187a]) and so the present pencil foliation must have been added to the volume prior to the publication of his Catalogue of the Jesus College manuscripts in 1895.

supportDesc.collation:
A composite manuscript with a complex structure. This collation distinguishes between composite parts (divided by a vertical bar: | ) and contemporary codicological units within these (divided by a semi-colon ; ).
Two parchment flyleaves (ff. 1-2) +
Quires 1-188 (ff. 3-50, [50a], 51-73 ; 74-145) |
Quire 1910 (ff. 146-155)
Quire 20-238 (ff. 156-160, [160a], 161-186)
Quire 244-2 (ff. 187, [187a]: 3rd and 4th leaves excised, probably blank) |
Quires 25-288 (ff. 188-211 ; 212-219)
Quire 2910-1 (ff. 220-221, [221a], 222-227v: 1st leaf cancelled)
Quires 30-348 (ff. 228-243 ; 244-259 ; 260-267) |
Quire 354 (ff. [267a]-270: two nested bifolia, 1st leaf (f. [267a] just a text-stub, and second leaf partially cut away)
Two parchment flyleaves + 1-188 1910 20-238 244-2 (3rd and 4th leaves excised, probably blank) | 25-288 2910-1 (1st leaf cancelled) 30-348 | 35 4 (1st leaf just a text-stub, second leaf partially cut away)
No leaf signatures common to the entire volume.
No quire signatures common to the entire volume. No catchwords common to the entire volume.

note.p: On f. 1v, a possible former ownership inscription, the first part very faint: 'Istum librum e tra... t... Joh. Walsh. Constat magistro Thome Audley et Roberto Swann Fortitudo et honor'. The note appears to continue under the bookplate on f. 1v.

On f. 2v, a couplet on stain removal in Latin: 'Uinum lacte laues oleum liquore fabarum
Incaustum uino cetera mundat aqua' (Wash wine with milk and oil with the soaking-water of beans
Ink with wine, everything else with clean water).

additions.note:
On f. 2v-3r, an early modern list of the contents of the volume as follows (numbering by the scribe):
1. Elucidarium Anonymi
2. Anselmi sermo . Ad interioris hominis custodiam &
3. Uita B. Mariae Secundum S. Hieronymum
4. Riche Hampole tractatus notabilis de aedificatione spirituali &
5. Tractatus de Decalogo et decem plagis Agypti
6. Summa confessionis Roberti de de
7. Ligni crucis historia ab Adamo e deducta
8. Petitiones et orationes Domini et octo ... Euangelicae &
9. Sententiae e patribus collecta
10. A treatise of ye soul of man
11. A treatise of medicins by Aleyn ye leche
12. Expositio quatuor partium anni &
13. Sermones de Sanctis

binding.p: Medieval binding, probably 15th century. Fully bound in tawed skin stained a deep red-purple over wooden boards. Traces of a strap-and-pin fastening present as a hole for a strap in the centre of the fore-edge of the left board, and a puncture mark for a now-lost pin-plate in the cover material over the centre of the right board. Three raised bands on spine. Head and tail bands visible and sewn with blue and yellow yarn, but very dirty and torn.
Paper pastedowns pasted over the turn ins, both blank.

Small paper label pasted around the fore edge of the right board, bearing the number '22', part of a former shelfmark. Some other Jesus College manuscripts, e.g., Cambridge, Jesus College, MS Q.B.10 had an additional label around the fore edge of the left board which contained another part of this former shelfmark scheme.
Stored in a dark green box with custom padding and a brown leather label with the shelfmark 'Q.D.4' stamped in gold on one of the outer faces.

accMat.note: Small parchment and paper tabs numbered in ink in Hindu-Arabic numerals along the fore edge of the volume; some tabs have clearly been lost, but the tab-sequence, which probably ran originally from 1-13 mirrors the division of the contents in a list on ff. 2v-3r, e.g., item 13 in that list, the 'Sermones de sanctis etc' matches tab 13.

provenance.p: Owned by a John Thrope John Thrope , whose name is present in a note written over a list of expenses on f. 269v, 'Memorandum quod iste liber constat domino Johanni Thrope pro quo habet in plegio librum de gestu romanorum domini A lax'.

acquisition.p: According to an inscription on f. 1r, 'Liber Colleg Jesu 1664', MS Q.D.4 has been a part of the Jesus College library collection since 1664. Jesus College MS Q.D.4 preserves several former Jesus College shelfmarks including 'M.Z.18' on f. 1r, 'H.18' in blue ink on f. 1r, and Q.Δ.4 (later updated to Q.D.4) on ff. 1r and 2v.

msItem.title: Table of contents
msItem.note: Transcription below based on an earlier interpolated transcription by M. R. James, note that the hand changes at 'Nichil a deo uenale ...': 'In hoc libello in nouo pergameno continentur quinque libri Elucidarii . sermones et capitulo qui sequntur . In primis post librum Elucidarij . Sermo sancti Anselmi Cantuariensis archiepiscopi Ad interioris hominis custodiam in quo sunt diuerse questiones . Prologus beati Ieronimi presbiteri de natiuitate beate Marie virginis et de uita eiusdem uirginis dei genitricis Marie . De incarnacione domini nostri Ihesu Christi Augustinus . Inter cetera et ad uidi portam in domo domini clausam . Iesse pater est . De originali peccato . De signis que uenerunt ante natiuitatem domini nostri Ihesu Christi et in tempore natiuitatis eius . Ne tardas conuerti ad dominum . Contempnere mundum etc . Si uis perfectus esse . Ut homo ad honorem dei . Cum diabolus uiderit . Non dedignentur filii regis . Si in tribulacione uel temptacione fueris . Est autem meditacio bona de passione christi . Si cupis ad amorem dei peruenire . Per hos nouem gradus pretaxatos . Dulce lumen et delectabile . Contemplacio uel uita contemplatiua . Oleum effusum nomen tuum . Cum infeliciter florem . Adolescentule dilexerunt te nimis . Decalogus est sermo breuis decem dei mandata continens . Item racionem decalogi . Quicunque uult confiteri . Sequitur de septem peccatis mortalibus exposicio secundum ordinem . Nota quod duplex est uita . Post peccatum Ade eodem expulso de paradiso . Mirabiliter oriri cepit sancta arbor . Septem sunt peticiones in oracione dominica . Nichil a deo uenale quod non fiat mortale . Paulus de penis inferni . Quod sola contricio non sufficit ad delendum peccatum sine confessione . Terribile erit cum dominus dicet surgite mortui . Diabolus ludit cum peccatore . Nota quod ubi aliquis tenet pomum . Si percipis coruum nidificare . Tria genera hominum designantur per ouem . De uii uiciis . Nemo uestimenta preciosa . Si uis corrigere delinquentem . Abbathia de spiritu sancto . De dieta et tonitruo duodecim mensium . Ypocrase de medisinis . De exposicione iiiior partium anni . Adam de octo partibus fuit factus . Tria sunt que uendicant hominem . De xiicim causis que omni homini timende sunt . Qui abscondit scelera sua . Que auferunt uenialia peccata . De significacione ecclesie . De significacione altaris . De diuite et lazaro'

msItem.title: Quatrain from the Altercacio Ganimedis et Helene
msItem.note:
Full transcription:
Cum plasmator hominis hominem formaret
Studuit ut feminam uiro plus ornaret
Ut ad nexum femine uirum inuitaret
Et ne plus quam feminam uirum uir amaret
This is an excerpt from the medieval poem Altercacio Ganimedis et Helene.

msItem.title: Quatrain
msItem.note:
Full transcription:
Si pro peccato ; uetus Adam non cecidisset
Uirgo pro nato ; non exaltata fuisset
Ergo pro miseris ; interpellare teneris
Que mater Christi ; propter peccata fuisti
This poem is untraced, although the first two lines are lines 3339ab in the medieval morality play The Castle of Perseverance, and a slightly longer version of the poem appears in the 15th century manuscript Cambridge, St John's College, MS E.26, f. 209v.

M. R. James breaks this item up at f. 144v, which he notes contains an extract from Jerome; the texts on ff. 142r-145v are largely comprised of branching diagrams on Christian themes and extracts from early Christian writers whose names (e.g., 'Ysidorus', 'Gregorius' 'Ieronimus' 'Augustinus' etc.,) are recorded in the outer margins.

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: Catchword present in the lower margin of f. 34v that provides the first capitulum heading on the next leaf, rather than the first word. Occasional 'traditional' catchwords throughout this Part, e.g., f. 81v.

supportDesc.condition: In good condition, although the fragility of the binding means that text close to the gutter can be difficult to read.

p.seg: Ruled in ink, frame and lines. Ruled in single-column format, typically 24 lines to the page and written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in an Anglicana minuscule with some Secretary features.

decoNote.p: Flourished initials executed with a rather blunt pen in red and black at some of the major and minor divisions of the text, see e.g., f. 74r.
Titles to works and minor divisions of the texts written in red.
Initials at the start of new 'sentences' often touched with red.

note.p: Notes in a late 16th or early 17th century hand on f. 73v describing the contents of the following leaves.

provenance.p: The text of the Emendatio uitae by Richard Rolle Rolle, Richard, 1290?-1349 in this manuscript, ff. 74r-99v is, according to Rüdiger Spahl, a direct copy of the same text in London, British Library, MS Harley 5235, ff. 1r-11v , a 14th century copy of the text. According to Spahl, MS Harley 5235 must have served as the direct exemplar for MS Jesus Q.D.4 as the two manuscripts contain fourteen shared textual omissions not found in any other copies of the text, and corrections made by the Harley scribe to the text of the Emendatio uitae after the main copying stint had been completed are also found in MS Q.D.4. Spahl supplies other evidence for the archetype-child relationship between these two manuscripts and positions both within his 'zeta' subgroup.

London, British Library, MS Harley 5235 is a composite manuscript, and the Part with the Emendatio uitae was apparently copied in the late-14th or early-15th century. Harley MS 5235 does not have a complete provenance, and its earliest known owner is a 'Thomas Baylle' who seems to have owned the manuscript in the 16th century, which is too late to provide any information about the origins of Jesus College MS Q.D.4.

msItem.title: Advice for diet and bloodletting
msItem.incipit: 172v Aleyn þe gode leche seiþ þat in þe mone of ianiuere wyte wynes is gode to drinke fastyng erly and blod latyng forbere
msItem.explicit: 173v and ho so þis lif he ... ledyth he may be seker of al his hele and iij dayes þer ben of perile . þe xv .day. and þe xvj .day. and þe xvij. day. si tontrus sonauerit annone uel abundancie et pacem inter gentes significant
msItem.note: Title added in the outer margin of f. 172v in ink in a later hand: Aleyn ye Leche of Medicins.

This text survives in several other manuscripts where it is often attributed to Galen; L. Mooney who prepared the IMEP volume (XI, p. 30) for Trinity College Cambridge, noted a version of this text in Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.7.23, ff. 256-257 , which also begins 'Aleyn þe god lech' and surmised that a 'G' had been lost from the incipit (i.e., it should have been '(G)alyen þe god lech'), and it is very likely that the same error occurs in this manuscript.
This copy corresponds with the (A) version of Lynne Mooney's typology of this text, described in 'Diet and Bloodletting: A monthly regimen' (esp. pp. 247-248).

A. M. Lucas in IMEP XXII notes that this is a 'short tratise attributed to Galen, translated from De phlebotomia, on monthly diet with instructions on perolous days for bloodletting, usually called Dieta Ypocratis.

msItem.note: Collection of short sermons written by several scribes who sometimes switch over mid-text, e.g., ff. 253v-254r.
Folio 259v blank.

msItem.title: Poem in Latin with Middle English glosses
msItem.note:
Short verse, possibly from the Gesta romanorum, in a late medieval hand on f. 267v: Spexus ovem geminam per spinam traxit equinam
Lesus surgit . equs pondum utrumque pecus
Ad molendinum pondus portabat ouinum
Dispergendo focum se cremat atque locum.
The poem is very similar to one found in the Gesta romanorum ch. 163 (Oesterley, 1872 edition), and appears by itself in a few other medieval manuscripts (see WIC 11754). The version of the poem in Cambridge, Jesus College, MS Q.D.4 lacks the final line Custodes aberant . singula dampna ferant. It should perhaps be noted that an inscription on f. 269v states that this volume (Q.D.4) was part of a trade by a John Thrope in exchange for a copy of the Gesta romanorum.

listBibl.bibl: H. Oesterley, Gesta romanorum (1872)

p.secFol: 189r: iohannes in templo et non solum in templo

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.

Medieval quire signatures 'vi' - 'ix' in the lower margins of the last versos of Quires 30-34. There are 5 preceding quires to Quire 30 in this Part, and so it is likely that medieval signatures 'i'-'v' have been trimmed away.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords present in the lower margin of the last verso of some quires in this Part, e.g., f. 219v.

supportDesc.condition: In fair condition. The binding on this volume is quite fragile due to age and so some of the text close to the inner margins is difficult to read. Some leaves are very dirty and rubbed and so some of the text is now rather difficult to read. Some marginal annotations lost to trimming.

p.seg: Folios 188r-259v and 262r-267v ruled in single column format, frame and lines, pricking visible in some outer margins. Ruled in ink and crayon, typically 34 lines to the page and written above top line.
Folios 260r-261v ruled in double-column format, frame and lines, pricking visible in outer and inner margins. Ruled in leadpoint, typically 33 lines to the page and written above top line.

handNote.p: Written in protogothic minuscule by at least 5 scribes, Scribe 1 writing ff. 188r-211v, Scribe 2 writing ff. 212r-243v, Scribe 3 writing ff. 244r-252r, Scribe 4 writing ff. 259r, Scribe 5 writing ff. 260r-261v, and Scribe 4 returning from ff. 261v-267v.

decoNote.p: Flourished initials in two main styles - the first are large 'arabesque' initials in red or green, e.g., f. 192v ('h'), f. 212r ('P') 260r ('S'), and the second are smaller, and in red and black, e.g., f. 235v ('D' and 'O'). Each style of initial is found accompanying the work of two or more of the scribes who copied this Part.
Rubricated titles to some sermons ff. 188r-212r only.

note.p: Marginal annotations throughout, typically small glosses to the text in ink, crayon and drypoint in contemporary and later medieval hands.
Erased notes in red-brown crayon in the lower half of f. 259r.
The words 'de quatuor que inpediunt confessionem' in ink in a late 12th or early 13th century hand in the upper margin of f. 238v.
The words 'mulier amicta sole' in ink in a late 12th or early 13th century hand the upper margin of f. 260r.

origin.origDate: Probably written in the last quarter of the 12th century or the first quarter of the 13th century.
origin.origPlace: Probably written in England, or perhaps France.

note.p: Date and place of production assigned based on palaeographical features.

msIdentifier.msName: Part 4 - A fragment of a Northamptonshire will and miscellaneous texts

msItem.title: Aphorisms
msItem.note:
Full transcription: Da tua dum tua sunt . post mortem tunc tua non sunt
Dum uius uiuunt . moriorum moriuntur amici
Mors facit immemores . quos vita tenebat amicos
Post mortis morsum uertit dilectio dorsum
Preterit ista dies nescitur origo secundi
An labor an requies sic transit gloria mundi

msItem.title: Notes on the national characteristics of the Spanish, French, Germans, Scottish, and English
Miscellaneous notes
msItem.note: Texts include what appears to be an exchange of books between a John Thrope and another person, where this book was given in exchange for a copy of the Gesta romanorum, and a list of expenses.

msItem.title: Fragment of a Northamptonshire will
msItem.note: Note that this leaf is upside down relative to the rest of the volume.

listBibl.bibl: See James, A Descriptive Catalogue of Manuscripts in the Library of Jesus College, Cambridge, no. 46, p. 74 for a transcription of what he could read of the will

collation.p:
Two nested bifolia, both very crumpled, the first leaf (f. [267a] substantially cut so that just a stub is visible, and the second leaf mutilated.
Quire 36 4 (two nested bifolia, 1st leaf a text-stub, and second leaf partially cut away; ff. [267a] recto-270)

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: In fair condition. All leaves in this part are wrinkled and some text is difficult to read due to the folds. The outer bifolium (ff. [267a]-270) in this Part is a will, and it has been mounted in the volume upside down and then half of the bifolium was cut away with a significant loss of text. The lower half of f. 268 has also been cut away.

p.seg: All leaves in this part are unruled and text is informally arranged on the leaves.

handNote.p: All leaves in this part written in various informal styles of 15th century cursiva by several scribes.

decoNote.p: No decoration particular to this Part.

note.p: Place and date of production assigned based on textual and palaeographical features.

provenance.p: The will on f. 270v mentions Northampton twice, so it is likely that the will originates from someone with a connection to that region.

revisionDesc.change: 2023-11-10: Dr Sarah Gilbert, Project Cataloguer for the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries project at Cambridge University Library.
